title: CLAUDE.md
text: oxidizr R package analyzing substrate oxidation exercise using indirect calorimetry stable isotope tracers. calculates carbohydrate, fat, protein oxidation rates optional partitioning exogenous vs endogenous carbohydrate sources using 13C isotope methods.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses S7 classes (S4 R6) data management. classes defined R/classes.R: CalorimetryData - VO2, VCO2, RER measurements configurable column mappings IsotopeData - 13C enrichment data (rexp, rexo, rref, rpla) UreaData - Sweat/urine urea concentrations protein oxidation EnvironmentData - Temperature, humidity, pressure SubjectData - Subject characteristics fluid balance OxidationStudy - Main container combining data components OxidationResults - Analysis output (oxidation rates, energy contributions, partitioning)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Calorimetry (R/calorimetry.R): read_calorimetry() → CalorimetryData Protein oxidation (R/protein.R): calc_sweat_loss() → calc_urea_loss() → calc_protein_oxidation() Substrate oxidation (R/oxidation.R): calc_substrate_oxidation() using stoichiometric equations Isotope analysis (R/isotopes.R): calc_rref() → calc_exogenous_cho() → calc_plasma_cho() CHO partitioning (R/oxidation.R): calc_cho_partition() exo/endo/muscle/liver sources Energy yield (R/energy.R): calc_energy_yield() → calc_energy_percent() main workflow function analyze_oxidation() orchestrates pipeline returns OxidationResults.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Defined R/oxidizr-package.R via stoich_coefficients: - CHO: 4.618 × VCO2 - 3.279 × VO2 (g/min) - Fat: -1.712 × VCO2 + 1.712 × VO2 (g/min) - CO2/CHO ratio: 0.747 L CO2 per gram CHO oxidized - Protein-urea conversion: 2.915 g protein per g urea

title: CLAUDE.md
text: S7 generics defined R/generics.R: - print() methods classes - summary() OxidationResults - get_data() extract underlying tibbles - .data.frame() conversions

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R/targets.R provides helpers reproducible pipelines: - tar_import_data() - Data import cleaning - tar_oxidation_analysis() - Full analysis workflow - tar_statistical_analysis() - Mixed ANOVAs (requires afex, emmeans) - tar_generate_figures() - Publication figures

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: vignette documents complete oxidizr analysis pipeline raw data import final reporting. pipeline consists six key stages: 1. Data Import - Reading data files creating data objects 2. Data Validation - Checking data quality physiological plausibility 3. Steady-State Detection - Identifying valid measurement periods 4. Processing & Aggregation - Filtering summarizing data 5. Oxidation Computation - Calculating substrate oxidation rates 6. Reporting - Generating visualizations, tables, reports

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: want get started immediately, ’s minimal workflow:
code: library(oxidizr)  # 1. Create or import data calo <- CalorimetryData(data = my_data)  # 2. Create study object study <- oxidation_study(calorimetry = calo)  # 3. Run complete analysis (includes validation) results <- analyze_oxidation(study, validate = TRUE)  # 4. Generate report render_oxidation_report(results)

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
code: library(oxidizr) library(dplyr)  # Simulated calorimetry data set.seed(42) calo_df <- tibble(   id = rep(1:5, each = 8),   protocol = rep(rep(c("Control", "Treatment"), each = 4), 5),   time = rep(c(30, 60, 90, 120), 10),   vo2 = 2.5 + rnorm(40, 0, 0.15),   vco2 = 2.3 + rnorm(40, 0, 0.12) ) |>   mutate(rer = vco2 / vo2)  # Create CalorimetryData object calo <- CalorimetryData(   data = calo_df,   id_col = "id",   time_col = "time",   vo2_col = "vo2",   vco2_col = "vco2",   vo2_unit = "L/min",   protocol_col = "protocol" )  print(calo)

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: Data validation critical ensuring physiologically plausible results. oxidizr validation system checks: Range validation: Values within physiological limits Missing data: Completeness assessment Outlier detection: Statistical outliers using IQR method Consistency: Cross-dataset alignment (IDs, time points)

text: can customize validation thresholds specific population:

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: Reliable oxidation calculations require steady-state conditions. package provides two methods detecting steady-state:

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: Based Robergs et al. (2010), method identifies periods CV falls threshold:
code: # Detect steady-state using CV method ss_cv <- detect_steady_state_cv(   calo,   variable = "vo2",   cv_threshold = 0.10,   # 10% CV threshold   window_size = 3,        # 3-point rolling window   min_duration = 2        # Minimum 2 consecutive points )  head(ss_cv) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>      id  time   vo2      cv is_steady steady_period meets_duration #>   <int> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl>             <int> <lgl>          #> 1     1    30  2.71 NA      FALSE                 0 FALSE          #> 2     1    30  2.56 NA      FALSE                 0 FALSE          #> 3     1    60  2.42  0.0567 TRUE                  1 TRUE           #> 4     1    60  2.48  0.0292 TRUE                  1 TRUE           #> 5     1    90  2.55  0.0280 TRUE                  1 TRUE           #> 6     1    90  2.73  0.0482 TRUE                  1 TRUE

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: method uses rolling variance detect stable periods:
code: # Detect using variance method ss_var <- detect_steady_state_variance(   calo,   variable = "vo2",   window_size = 5 )

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: robustness, combine methods:
code: # Combined detection on both VO2 and VCO2 ss_result <- detect_steady_state(   calo,   variables = c("vo2", "vco2"),   cv_threshold = 0.10,   method = "both",          # Use both CV and variance   combine_method = "and",   # Both must agree   verbose = FALSE )  # View steady-state summary tbl_steady_state(ss_result)

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
code: plot_steady_state(ss_result)

code: # Get only steady-state observations ss_data <- filter_steady_state(calo, ss_result)  # Calculate statistics during steady-state ss_stats <- calc_steady_state_stats(calo, ss_result, variables = c("vo2", "vco2")) print(ss_stats) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0

title: Complete Analysis Pipeline
text: ’s complete end--end example:
code: library(oxidizr)  # ============================================ # STAGE 1: DATA IMPORT # ============================================  # Read calorimetry data calo <- read_cosmed_csv("data/calorimetry.csv")  # Read subject data subjects <- SubjectData(data = read.csv("data/subjects.csv"))  # Create study study <- oxidation_study(   calorimetry = calo,   subjects = subjects )  # ============================================ # STAGE 2: DATA VALIDATION # ============================================  # Validate and generate quality report validation <- validate_study(study) print(validation)  # Generate quality report if issues found if (!validation@passed) {   render_quality_report(study, validation = validation) }  # ============================================ # STAGE 3: STEADY-STATE DETECTION # ============================================  # Detect steady-state periods ss_result <- detect_steady_state(   calo,   variables = c("vo2", "vco2"),   cv_threshold = 0.10,   method = "both" )  # Filter to steady-state only calo_ss <- filter_steady_state(calo, ss_result)  # ============================================ # STAGE 4: PROCESSING # ============================================  # Update study with filtered data study_ss <- oxidation_study(   calorimetry = calo_ss,   subjects = subjects )  # ============================================ # STAGE 5: OXIDATION COMPUTATION # ============================================  # Run complete analysis results <- analyze_oxidation(   study_ss,   time_range = c(30, 120),   calc_energy = TRUE,   validate = FALSE  # Already validated )  # ============================================ # STAGE 6: REPORTING # ============================================  # Generate final report render_oxidation_report(results, output_file = "final_report.html")  # Export tables to Excel export_table_xlsx(   tbl_oxidation_summary(results),   file = "oxidation_summary.xlsx" )  # Save figures ggsave(   "oxidation_timecourse.png",   plot_oxidation_timecourse(results),   width = 10, height = 6 )

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: Data quality fundamental reliable substrate oxidation analysis. oxidizr package provides comprehensive validation tools : Verify data types structure Check values within physiological ranges Detect outliers missing data Identify steady-state periods Generate quality reports vignette covers validation features detail.
code: library(oxidizr) library(dplyr)

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: validation functions return ValidationResult S7 object containing:

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: Issues categorized severity: error: Critical issues may invalidate results warning: Potential problems worth investigating info: Informational notes

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: main entry point comprehensive validation:
code: # Create sample data with some issues set.seed(42) df <- tibble(   id = rep(1:3, each = 5),   time = rep(c(0, 30, 60, 90, 120), 3),   vo2 = c(2.5, 2.6, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6,           0.15, 2.5, 2.6, 7.5, 2.5,  # Subject 2: out of range           2.5, NA, 2.6, 2.5, 2.6),    # Subject 3: missing   vco2 = c(2.3, 2.4, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4,            2.3, 2.4, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4,            2.3, 2.4, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4) ) |>   mutate(rer = vco2 / vo2)  calo <- CalorimetryData(data = df) study <- oxidation_study(calorimetry = calo)  # Validate validation <- validate_study(study, verbose = TRUE)

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: Substrate oxidation calculations assume steady-state conditions. Non-steady data can lead : Inaccurate RER values Unreliable oxidation estimates Increased measurement noise

title: Data Validation & Quality Control
text: Based Robergs et al. (2010):
code: # Coefficient of variation method ss_cv <- detect_steady_state_cv(   calo,   variable = "vo2",   cv_threshold = 0.10,  # 10% CV   window_size = 3 )  # View CV values ss_cv |>   select(id, time, vo2, cv, is_steady, meets_duration) |>   head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 6 #>       id  time   vo2      cv is_steady meets_duration #>    <int> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl>     <lgl>          #>  1     1     0  2.5  NA      FALSE     FALSE          #>  2     1    30  2.6  NA      FALSE     FALSE          #>  3     1    60  2.4   0.0400 TRUE      TRUE           #>  4     1    90  2.5   0.0400 TRUE      TRUE           #>  5     1   120  2.6   0.0400 TRUE      TRUE           #>  6     2     0  0.15 NA      FALSE     FALSE          #>  7     2    30  2.5  NA      FALSE     FALSE          #>  8     2    60  2.6   0.792  FALSE     FALSE          #>  9     2    90  7.5   0.681  FALSE     FALSE          #> 10     2   120  2.5   0.681  FALSE     FALSE

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: oxidizr package provides tools analyzing substrate oxidation exercise using indirect calorimetry stable isotope tracers. vignette demonstrates basic workflow analyzing oxidation data.

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
code: # Install from local source devtools::install("path/to/oxidizr")  # Or from GitHub (when available) # remotes::install_github("jtremblay/oxidizr")

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
code: library(oxidizr) library(ggplot2)

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: example, ’ll create simulated calorimetry data:
code: # Simulated calorimetry data calo_df <- data.frame(   id = rep(1:5, each = 4),   protocol = rep(c("Control", "Treatment"), each = 10),   time = rep(c(30, 60, 90, 120), 5),   vo2 = rnorm(20, mean = 2.5, sd = 0.2),   vco2 = rnorm(20, mean = 2.3, sd = 0.2) )  # Preview the data head(calo_df) #>   id protocol time      vo2     vco2 #> 1  1  Control   30 2.219991 2.393631 #> 2  1  Control   60 2.551063 2.372590 #> 3  1  Control   90 2.012547 2.039091 #> 4  1  Control  120 2.498886 2.447555 #> 5  2  Control   30 2.624311 2.677701 #> 6  2  Control   60 2.729682 2.280511

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: first step wrap data S7 class:
code: calo <- CalorimetryData(   data = calo_df,   id_col = "id",   time_col = "time",   vo2_col = "vo2",   vco2_col = "vco2",   vo2_unit = "L/min",   protocol_col = "protocol" )  # Print summary print(calo) #>  #> ── CalorimetryData ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> • Subjects: 5 #> • Time points: 4 #> • Observations: 20 #> • VO2 unit: L/min #> • Protocols: Control, Treatment

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: Use calc_substrate_oxidation() function calculate CHO fat oxidation:
code: oxidation <- calc_substrate_oxidation(calo)  # View results head(oxidation) #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>      id  time protocol cho_total fat_total protein_ox   rer rer_np vo2_lmin #>   <int> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1     1    30 Control       3.77    0               0 1.08   1.08      2.22 #> 2     1    60 Control       2.59    0.306           0 0.930  0.930     2.55 #> 3     1    90 Control       2.82    0               0 1.01   1.01      2.01 #> 4     1   120 Control       3.11    0.0879          0 0.979  0.979     2.50 #> 5     2    30 Control       3.76    0               0 1.02   1.02      2.62 #> 6     2    60 Control       1.58    0.769           0 0.835  0.835     2.73 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: vco2_lmin <dbl>

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: Convert oxidation rates energy yield percentages:
code: energy <- calc_energy_yield(oxidation) energy <- calc_energy_percent(energy)  # View energy percentages energy |>   dplyr::select(id, time, pct_cho_total, pct_fat, e_total) |>   head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>      id  time pct_cho_total pct_fat e_total #>   <int> <dbl>         <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1     1    30         100      0       14.0 #> 2     1    60          77.0   23.0     12.5 #> 3     1    90         100      0       10.5 #> 4     1   120          93.3    6.69    12.4 #> 5     2    30         100      0       14.0 #> 6     2    60          44.8   55.2     13.1

code: tbl_oxidation_summary(results, by = "protocol")

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: studies using 13C-labeled substrates, can calculate exogenous carbohydrate oxidation:
code: # Create isotope data iso_data <- IsotopeData(   rexp = rexp_df,    # Expired CO2 enrichment   rexo = rexo_df,    # Exogenous substrate enrichment   rref = rref_df,    # Reference enrichment   rpla = rpla_df     # Plasma glucose enrichment (optional) )  # Create study object study <- oxidation_study(   calorimetry = calo,   isotopes = iso_data )  # Run complete analysis results <- analyze_oxidation(   study,   time_range = c(30, 120),   control_protocol = "Control" )  # Plot CHO partitioning plot_cho_partition(results, by = "protocol")

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: package uses stoichiometric equations carbohydrate fat oxidation. based general principles (Livesey & Elia, 1988) specific coefficients parameterized presented Telmosse (2022), derived Institute Medicine (2005) data. Carbohydrate oxidation: CHO(g/min)=4.618×VCO2−3.279×VO2CHO\ (g/min) = 4.618 \times VCO_2 - 3.279 \times VO_2 Fat oxidation: Fat(g/min)=−1.712×VCO2+1.712×VO2Fat\ (g/min) = -1.712 \times VCO_2 + 1.712 \times VO_2

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: using 13C tracers, formula exogenous carbohydrate oxidation utilizes CO2/CHO conversion ratio 0.747 L CO2 per gram CHO oxidized (Péronnet & Massicotte, 1991; Telmosse, 2022). CHOexo=VCO2×(Rexp−Rref)(Rexo−Rref)×0.747CHO_{exo} = \frac{VCO_2 \times (R_{exp} - R_{ref})}{(R_{exo} - R_{ref}) \times 0.747}

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: Default energy conversion factors (kcal/g) based Institute Medicine (2005): - Carbohydrate: 3.72 - Fat: 9.44 - Protein: 4.70

title: Getting Started with oxidizr
text: Institute Medicine, Food Nutrition Board. (2005). Dietary Reference Intakes Energy, Carbohydrate, Fiber, Fat, Fatty Acids, Cholesterol, Protein, Amino Acids. National Academies Press. Livesey, G., & Elia, M. (1988). Estimation energy expenditure, net carbohydrate utilization, net fat oxidation synthesis indirect calorimetry: evaluation errors special reference detailed composition fuels. American Journal Clinical Nutrition, 47(4), 608–628. Péronnet, F., & Massicotte, D. (1991). Table nonprotein respiratory quotient: update. Canadian Journal Sport Sciences = Journal Canadien Des Sciences Du Sport, 16(1), 23–29. Telmosse, E. (2022). Contribution des glucides exogènes à la fourniture d’énergie lors d’un effort prolongé : analyse par régression multiple. Mémoire de maîtrise, Université de Montréal.

text: formula exogenous carbohydrate oxidation utilizes CO2/CHO conversion ratio 0.747 L CO2 per gram CHO oxidized (Péronnet & Massicotte, 1991; Telmosse, 2022).

title: Calculate Protein Oxidation from Urea — calc_protein_oxidation
text: conversion factor 2.915 derived work Telmosse (2022), states 1 gram urea excreted equivalent 0.343 grams protein oxidized. value based protein formula (C89H148.5O32N23.5) described Institute Medicine (2005). Nitrogen content proteins (~16%) Nitrogen content urea (46.6%) Complete oxidation amino acids protein_ox = urea_mass * 2.915 / exercise_duration

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
code: calc_substrate_oxidation(   calo,   protein_ox = NULL,   coefficients = stoich_coefficients,   na_protein_action = c("mean", "zero", "error") )

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
text: calo CalorimetryData object protein_ox Optional protein oxidation data (calc_protein_oxidation) coefficients Stoichiometric coefficients (default: stoich_coefficients) na_protein_action handle NA values protein oxidation data. One : "mean" (default): Replace NA group mean, 0 NA "zero": Replace NA 0 (assume negligible protein contribution) "error": Raise error NA values present

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
text: tibble CHO fat oxidation rates (g/min)

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
text: Uses equations commonly attributed Jequier et al. Frayn, specific coefficients parameterized presented Telmosse (2022): Non-protein calculations: VO2np = VO2 - (protein_ox * 1.0075) VCO2np = VCO2 - (protein_ox * 0.8443) Substrate oxidation: CHO (g/min) = 4.618 * VCO2np - 3.279 * VO2np Fat (g/min) = -1.712 * VCO2np + 1.712 * VO2np

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
text: protein oxidation data contains NA values, na_protein_action parameter controls behavior: "mean": Imputes missing values mean available protein oxidation values. values NA, uses 0. preserves group average contribution may appropriate studies large inter-subject variability. "zero": Treats missing protein oxidation zero contribution. Appropriate protein contribution expected negligible (< 5% total energy) conservative estimates preferred. "error": Raises error NA values present. Recommended automated pipelines missing data halt processing.

title: Calculate Substrate Oxidation — calc_substrate_oxidation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic calculation (assuming negligible protein contribution) ox <- calc_substrate_oxidation(calo_data)  # With protein correction protein <- calc_protein_oxidation(urea_loss) ox <- calc_substrate_oxidation(calo_data, protein_ox = protein)  # Strict mode for automated pipelines ox <- calc_substrate_oxidation(calo_data, protein_ox = protein,                                na_protein_action = "error") } # }

title: Detect Steady-State Using Combined Methods — detect_steady_state
text: CV variance-based methods require sufficient data points within window. fewer 3 subjects limited time points: Consider reducing window_size_cv window_size_var data sparse CV calculations may unstable small samples Visual inspection individual subject traces recommended Default thresholds validated samples n >= 5 subjects

title: Detect Steady-State Using Combined Methods — detect_steady_state
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Combined detection on VO2 and VCO2 ss <- detect_steady_state(calo_data, variables = c("vo2", "vco2"))  # Use only CV method ss_cv <- detect_steady_state(calo_data, method = "cv", cv_threshold = 0.08)  # Accept steady-state if EITHER method indicates it ss_or <- detect_steady_state(calo_data, method = "both", combine_method = "or") } # }

title: oxidizr: Substrate Oxidation Analysis During Exercise — oxidizr-package
text: Extreme RER Values: RER < 0.70: Physiologically impossible. Indicates measurement error, gas analyzer calibration issues, data entry problems. values flagged errors validate_study(). RER 0.70-0.75: Unusually low exercise. May indicate high fat oxidation, prolonged fasting, measurement drift. Review data potential issues. RER 0.95-1.00: Approaching anaerobic threshold. Consider whether exercise intensity appropriate substrate oxidation assessment. RER > 1.00: Indicates hyperventilation, non-steady state, anaerobic metabolism. Data 1.10 excluded substrate oxidation calculations. Small Sample Sizes (< 3 subjects): Statistical analyses (standard deviation, coefficient variation) may unreliable fewer 3 subjects. Steady-state detection CV thresholds validated larger samples; use caution n < 3. Consider reporting individual subject data rather group means small samples. Missing Data (NA values): calc_substrate_oxidation() offers three NA handling strategies via na_protein_action parameter: "mean" (impute group mean), "zero" (assume negligible protein), "error" (strict validation). Validation functions report missing data patterns help identify systematic vs. random missingness. isotope calculations, missing rref values can provided numeric constants calculated control protocol data.
